Augmentus

A tool designed to assist in active tabletop games, saving you time and keeping you focused on gameplay.

There was an augmented reality (AR) tool floating around that was trying to replace Warhammer models with virtual ones on the tabletop.

This is not that.

Warhammer 40K is about more than just the game - the lore, the art, the craftsmanship and so much more all play into the immersion and enjoyment of this hobby. The bane of the tabletop is the time spent checking distances, trying to figure out rule interactions, and (mis)calculating wounds and armor saves.

Those issues are the ones we are going to attempt to overcome with this technology - we are going to enhance the tabletop experience, not replace it.

Phase I - Measuring

At a glance with your phone camera, you should be able to see a movement or firing range (or a combination) circle for any given model projected on the tabletop using AR technologies. This would allow you to more easily see possible moves, leaving more time for strategizing and less time trying not to knock over half the units with your fat, stubby fingers while touching everything with your measuring tape.*
*Author may be projecting his own experiences

There are some considerations here:

  • Each model needs to be marked in a way that the processor can recognize it. Full model recognition is probably not practical quite yet for a phone (maybe it is though, we are going to look into it). This is often done with QR markers that can be printed off easily, but there may be a way to use specialized colors around the edge of base or something similar.
  • You will have to have your model data available. We cannot provide it for you, given Games Workshop’s intellectual property ownership - Unless they want to give us permission to use it? Pretty please? (We can probably consume your program that shall not be named army list files).
  • Accuracy may be temperamental. We are still researching, so we will see if the accuracy is up-to-snuff in a situation where 1/4” matters.
  • Alternatively, there may be a simple way to recognize “a model”, but you need to select which model from a datasheet. Or even more simple: just a slider to set distance that can then be projected for every model recognized on the battlefield.

Phase II - Interaction

What was the strength on that weapon again? What’s the toughness on the target unit? My AP? Your armor save? Did you have an invuln? Wait, didn’t that guy have a feel-no-pain? Arg, I forgot my mortal wounds.

No more. You and your opponent connect army lists wirelessly, and you can easily select which unit is shooting with which weapon profile at which enemy unit with a couple of touches. See ability interactions without flipping through the rule book, codex, and supplements for fifteen minutes. See expanded explanations of those interactions for tricky situations based on feedback from wargammers the world over.

  • Is actually completely separable from Phase I - essentially two different tools in the same app.
  • Again, all data has to be user-entered unless… Geedubs? You reading this? Tell us this wouldn’t be the most awesome thing to happen to tabletop gaming since the invention of dice.
  • It could have an auto-roller built in - but by no means should that be mandatory or even enabled by default. Dice rolling is fun and exciting. The option could be there for those that want to expedite gameplay further.

Current status

We put up this page. That’s about as far as we have gotten on this endeavor. If you’d like to keep up with our progress, follow our Facebook or Twitter pages or even hop on our Patreon!

If you want to be involved we probably won’t turn down help. Contact us through any of our channels or email us.

If you like what you see, share it!
